metadata.title: CASE 280/04: Investigation into Allegations of Irregularities in Tender Processes at Pristina Airport

overview: This report details the investigation into allegations of irregularities during tender processes for procuring cleaning machines at Pristina Airport.

applicable_laws.excerpt: ...the law applicable in Kosovo shall be the regulations promulgated by the Special Representative of the Secretary-General...
...“Staff members shall uphold the highest standards of efficiency, competence and integrity”
...“Competition among and participation in the procurement process shall be maximised.”
Technical specifications and descriptions of the Goods, Works, or Services to be procured shall be carefully prepared to foster fair and open competition among all suppliers.

There shall be no requirements or reference in the technical specifications to a particular trademark, brand name... unless there is no sufficiently precise or intelligible way of describing the procurement requirements and 'or equivalent' are included.

Failure by a staff member to comply with obligations under the Charter of the United Nations or to observe the standards of conduct expected may amount to unsatisfactory conduct leading to disciplinary measures.

methodology.description: This investigation was conducted pursuant to Executive Decision No 2003/16 on the establishment of the Investigation Task Force. The ITF investigators conducted an enquiry into the allegations.
interviews: Interviews with persons indicated to be witnesses and persons potentially implicated in the allegations
documents_reviewed: Documents obtained from the Pristina Airport administration and from Pillar IV for relevance to the inquiry

background.context: The investigation was prompted by an audit report concerning the financial statements of Pristina International Airport.

investigation_details.subject: Irregularities in tender processes for cleaning machines

allegations.description: No proper description of the cabins for cleaning machines in the bid submissions.
allegations.findings: Bids were opened on 2003-04-18 and later cancelled on 2003-06-06 due to irregularities in cabin descriptions. ITF finds no evidence that the first tender was irregularly cancelled.

allegations.description: Tender specifications skewed towards one company by using a specific brochure.
allegations.findings: Specifications were based on Vendor 1's brochure, ignoring Financial Administration Instruction No. 2/1999.

allegations.description: Evaluation of bids raised concerns over cost and potential unfair advantage in the second tender.
allegations.findings: Vendor 2's bid, despite being expensive, met specifications. Concerns over resemblance to Vendor 1's specifications raised doubts.

sources: Interviews with Procurement Officers and Engineers at the Airport
Internet search on Vendor 1's corporate history
key_findings: Vendor 1's brochure was used for technical specifications but did not submit a bid.
Vendor 2 was chosen despite high costs due to specification alignment.
assessments: Specification process may have inadvertently favored certain vendors.
High cost of the selected bid raised concerns regarding the procurement process.
risks: Potential loss of competitive tendering environment.
Perceived procurement bias could affect institutional transparency.

findings: Use of Vendor 1's brochure in technical specifications created procurement bias.
Cancellation of tenders resulted from issues concerning fairness and cost.

actions: Revise technical specification processes to ensure competitiveness.
Consider conducting a new tender with neutral specifications.
Report referral to D/SRSG Pillar IV to avoid biased technical specifications.
